spans.content: From invitation to destination: A systematic literature review of the use of picturebooks in inquiry-based education
Rowan Oberman
Institute of Education, Dublin City University, Dublin, Ireland
Correspondence
Rowan Oberman, Institute of Education, Dublin City University, St Patrick's Campus, Dublin 9, Ireland.
Email: rowan.oberman@dcu.ie
Abstract

Picturebooks offer powerful supports for teaching diverse content across different curriculum areas. Research and curriculum resources document their use in inquiry-based education practices, particularly in relation to science and philosophy. There is, however, little theoretical analysis of this use or cross-curricular comparisons. Applying a systematic literature review process, this paper examines existing empirical research on the use of picturebooks in formal inquiry-based education contexts. The analysis considers the context in which the picturebooks were used, including curriculum context and class level, the role played by the picturebooks in the inquiries and the value ascribed to the use of picturebooks. The review proposes a framework for understanding and contrasting the varying roles played by picturebooks in inquiry-based education approaches. This framework involves seven uses: invitations, provocations, mentors, models, resources, touchstones and destinations. Varying benefits are attributed to the use of picturebooks, including their practicality, inclusivity, complexity, aid to cognitive learning, emotional engagement and association with child readers. These benefits emphasise both the accessibility and the complexity of picturebooks. The review proposes that inquiry approaches should attend to picturebook form and content and the interdependency of the two. The review's analysis supports extended use of picturebooks across the curriculum, including in

This is an open access article under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License, which permits use, distribution and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.

Received: 6 April 2022
Accepted: 2 February 2023
ORIGINAL ARTICLE
BERJ BERA
wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/berj
history, geography, citizenship and science education, as well as in interdisciplinary approaches.
KEYWORDS
inquiry, inquiry-based science, philosophy for children, picturebooks
Key insights
What is the main issue that the paper addresses?

The use of picturebooks in inquiry-based education is under-theorised, particularly in cross-curricular contexts. There is limited analysis of how picturebooks support the inquires and the value attributed to their use.
What are the main insights that the paper provides?

Picturebooks are used in inquiry-based education in seven ways and for three purposes. As invitations and destinations, they orientate the inquiries. As provocations and touchstone texts, they provide a shared imagined space to explore ideas and experiences. As mentor texts, models and resources, they provide tools for the learning content.
INTRODUCTION

There is no singular definition of 'picturebooks', with many characteristics being as quickly contradicted as they are defined. Some suggest the term is reserved for books with aesthetic complexity, or a child readership or for narrative fiction (Nodelman, 1988; Roche, 2015; Salisbury & Styles, 2020). The term 'picturebooks', however, is used to encompass a broad spectrum including adult (Ommundsen, 2014), informational (Von Merveldt, 2018), non-narrative (Boggs et al., 2016), wordless (Arizpe, 2013) and those with elementary content, as well as those celebrated for their complexity, sophistication and subversion (Dresang, 2003; Hassett & Curwood, 2009; Haynes & Murris, 2012). Consistently, however, picturebooks are recognised as being multimodal artefacts where the images play a significant role in the reading experience, contrasting with illustrated books where they supplement the text (Arizpe, 2021; Dresang, 2003; Hassett & Curwood, 2009). The relationship between the words and images can be collaborative or contradictory, with the two either reinforcing the same or else providing alternative narratives (Nikolajeva & Scott, 2001; Nodelman, 1988). They are most often written by adults (Tomsic & Zbaracki, 2022) and associated with children; their value for (young) adult readers and learners under-appreciated (Haynes & Murris, 2017).

Picturebooks instigate academic interest from different perspectives, including literary and educational. Arizpe (2021) categorises current picturebook research (from 2010 to 2020) into four strands: aesthetic; material, exploring the multisensory experience of reading; socio-cultural, focusing on authenticity and representation; and educational. In an educational context, Arizpe highlights picturebook use for literacy, visual literacy, multicultural and multilingual learning. She also identifies picturebooks about migration and environmentalism as areas of research growth. Like others (Haynes & Murris, 2012; Khosronejad & Shokrollahzadeh, 2020; Roche, 2015; Shimek, 2019), Arizpe challenges approaches
BERJ
OBERMAN

which ignore picturebook aesthetics by instrumentalising them to teach literacy or thematic messages. The artistry, multimodality and often ambiguity affords immersive experiences which can support more dialogic, reflective and critical pedagogies. Arizpe's overview presents diverse approaches to picturebook study which prioritise their content and impact on readers, but little consider the pedagogical contexts in which they are used. In addition to this research, curriculum-focused studies explore picturebook use within different curriculum areas, particularly in early childhood education. Research and curriculum resources exploring pedagogical uses of picturebooks can be found in relation to literacy (e.g., Hassett & Curwood, 2009; Pike et al., 2010), maths (e.g., Björklund & Palmér, 2020; Capraro & Capraro, 2006), science (e.g., Ansberry & Morgan, 2010; Sackes et al., 2009), history (e.g., Brugar, 2019; Youngs, 2012) and citizenship education (e.g., Dolan, 2014; Rapanta et al., 2021). Many of these research studies and curriculum resources map where picturebook and curriculum content match. They propose that the thematic content in picturebooks be used to reinforce or introduce concepts and learning. The exploration of pedagogical approaches and the theory underpinning picturebook use is less explored (Arizpe, 2021).

Inquiry-based pedagogical approaches are promoted across curriculum areas. Here, picturebooks are amongst the resources used in the inquiries, although this use is little analysed or theorised, particularly from a cross-curricular perspective. Recognising learning as taking place through complex interactions between the picturebooks, the pedagogical approaches, the classroom dialogue and the individual student, this review focuses on, and attempts to systematically capture, the use of the picturebook in the inquiry context. In this way, this review differs from reader-response studies which focus on the interaction of the readers and the texts (Hope, 2015; Rosenblatt, 1978). It seeks to map existing empirical research in formal education settings which explores the use of picturebooks, focusing specifically on the role played by picturebooks and the value they bring to the inquiries. In so doing, this review provides a theoretical frame for considering diverse and cross-curricular use, supporting extended use of picturebooks in inquiry-based education and cross-disciplinary learning.
PICTUREBOOKS AND INQUIRY-BASED EDUCATION: TOWARDS A FRAMEWORK

Inquiry as an education orientation is credited to Dewey (Barrow, 2006). Dewey (1910) critiques the separation of academic abstract knowledge and the practice of applying that knowledge. He advocates for practices which involve learners in the generation of knowledge, rather than presenting knowledge as a priori fact. For Dewey, understanding the scientific process is as important as understanding scientific conclusions and being familiar with established knowledge. Critical thinking is required, including assessing evidence, formulating hypotheses and searching for reasons. Dewey also highlights the importance of considering in education the application of scientific understandings (i.e., what is done with science), which involves social and ethical considerations as well as considering the processes themselves (the 'how' of science).

Where Dewey's focus is predominantly on science, inquiry-based learning is now promoted across discipline areas in national policies and curricula (Barrow, 2006; Levy et al., 2013; Short & Burke, 1996). While definitions, emphasis and practices in inquiry-based approaches vary (Barrow, 2006; Levy et al., 2013), generalisations can be drawn which hold true across disciplines. Inquiry-based education is seen as question and problem driven (Harlen, 2012). Very often, students are active in developing the questions to be explored. Where they are preset, they should be of interest to students (Barrow, 2006). Inquiry-based approaches see students involved in gathering knowledge for a purpose (Dewey, 1910;
REVIEW OF PICTUREBOOKS AND INQUIRY
BERJ

Harlen, 2012; Short, 2018). They should involve critical engagement with the materials: analysing, evaluating, considering alternatives, hypothesising or testing ideas (Barrow, 2006; Dewey, 1910; Murris, 2016). Inquiry approaches draw on, but go beyond, students' previous knowledge (Harlen, 2012). Furthermore, they are in some way collaborative (Harste, 2001) with dialogue, not only addressing the focus of the inquiry, but building students' critical thinking through the internalisation of inter-subject discussion (Daniel & Auriac, 2011). Drawing conclusions and the presentation of these is often regarded as an important aspect of inquiry (Barrow, 2006). As well as an important educational content outcome (inquiry as ends), inquiry is also understood across disciplines as an effective pedagogical approach (inquiry as means) and an attitude or habit of mind, what has been referred to as 'inquiry as stance' (Cochran-Smith & Lytle, 2015).

One inquiry-based area where the pedagogical use of picturebooks is well theorised is philosophy for children (P4C) (Haynes & Murris, 2012; Khosronejad & Shokrollahzadeh, 2020; Murris, 2014, 2016). Khosronejad and Shokrollahzadeh (2020) compare approaches to picturebooks within P4C scholarship, contrasting the rejection of picturebooks by Matthew Lipman to the promotion of picturebooks by subsequent scholars. They criticise instrumental approaches which overlook picturebook artistry to extract useful philosophical content. Murris, Haynes and others, by contrast, engage with children's literary scholarship and value picturebooks' creative dynamics. For Haynes and Murris (2012), the immersive and emotional experiences provided by the picturebooks are themselves a source of knowledge to inform the inquiries. The Haynes and Murris (2012) approach is rooted in Martha Nussbaum's work on literature and philosophy. Nussbaum (1992) suggests that literature can both recreate subjective immersive experience and simultaneously provide omniscient reflection, aiding philosophical thinking in bringing together emotion and experience with rationality and reflection. Nussbaum also advocates that the form of writing is integral to the content of the knowledge being communicated. She contends that what is communicated by text is as much 'how' the text is written or portrayed as its paraphrasable content. Applying Nussbaum's contention to picturebooks is to propose that their craft contributes to the thematic ideas they communicate. Part of what differentiates Haynes and Murris (and Nussbaum) from Lipman is the value they place on emotion as itself an ethical judgement and therefore an element of knowledge. The emotional experiences aroused by picturebooks therefore support philosophical discussion.

The Haynes and Murris (2012) P4C approach uses picturebooks in a community of philosophical inquiry (COPE), founded on democratic pedagogical principles. Learners dictate the inquiries' orientation, learning outcomes are open and knowledge is built collectively through reasoned discussion. Critical, ethical and philosophical thinking is developed with learners evaluating claims, empathising, exploring alternatives, hypothesising and giving reasons for their positions (Daniel & Auriac, 2011; Haynes, 2009). Murris (2014), for example, contrasts their use of picturebooks to other, more instrumental, literacy practices where the text is used for teaching a moral message, its purpose presented by the adult and the responses preconfigured. More recently, Haynes and Murris (2017, 2021) and Murris (2016) have sought not only to promote more child-led pedagogies, but to challenge developmental and colonial perspectives on childhood, measured as progression towards the rational singular adult. Approaching P4C from a critical post-humanist and new materialist perspective, they recognise meaning as created in the entanglement of human and non-human bodies and propose that inquiries be transdisciplinary, rooted in children's lived experiences, and allow multimodal responses. They also highlight the possibility of a 'post-age' curriculum, where philosophy for children and picturebooks create inter-generational learning spaces and where 'children' are defined by disposition rather than age span. Picturebooks with complexity and ambiguity are seen to best support philosophical inquiry, and these might include controversial and
BERJ
OBERMAN

sensitive themes (Haynes & Murris, 2012). Despite the democratic intentions of COPEs, the selecting of picturebooks is seen to afford the teacher residual censorship power (Haynes & Murris, 2012). Chetty (2017), writing particularly about the marginalisation of people of colour in P4C practices, highlights the significance of picturebook selection in determining what discussions are likely or unlikely. In demonstrating how picturebooks which depoliticise race might exclude minoritised students, he highlights how text choice and teacher approach can both open up and foreclose possible inquiry explorations.
METHODOLOGY

This review provides a meta-synthesis of empirical research studies exploring inquiry-based educational practices that use picturebooks in formal education settings (Siddaway et al., 2019; Thorne et al., 2004). As recommended (Siddaway et al., 2019; Thorne et al., 2004), the review is shaped by key questions: how can picturebooks be used to support inquiry-based education? What value do picturebooks bring to inquiry-based education? As a new area of study, the review also seeks to map research in this area, documenting class level, curriculum area, geographical area and methodology of the studies included. Recognising the challenges of synthesising diverse qualitative literature (Arksey & O'Malley, 2005; Thorne et al., 2004), the review seeks to capture the complexity and diversity of the research in this area as well as to identify key themes, concepts and theories related to the use of picturebooks in inquiry-based education.
Study search

Using Ebsco, four education databases (Education Research Complete, British Education Index, Education Full Text [H.W. Wilson] and ERIC) were searched. Different search terms and different fields were trialled including, for example: 'inquiry-based learning', 'children's literature', 'community of enquiry'. Those ultimately selected were seen to ensure inclusion of relevant studies and adequate refinement to ensure feasibility. Title, abstract, keywords and subject terms were searched using the terms 'picturebook* or 'picture book* or 'illustrated book* or 'picture storybook* with Boolean terms selected. Secondly, the same fields were searched using the terms 'inquir' or 'enquir*, also with Boolean terms selected. The two searches were then combined using 'and' so that results needed to include both a picturebook-related search term and an inquiry/enquiry-related term. The same process was then conducted in Scopus. Both search results were combined in Zotero and duplicates removed, leaving 152 articles. 'Picture book*' rendered the most results when combined with an inquiry/enquiry term. 'Picturebook' resulted in 23 of the studies, 'picture storybook' gave five and 'illustrated book' gave four, none of which were ultimately included in the review.

The abstracts of these 152 articles were scanned and 84 were included to review in full. After reviewing these, 15 met the inclusion criteria which are detailed below. All reviewing was conducted by this author. Most of the exclusions, either on abstract or full article review, were on the basis that no empirical research was documented or that the studies did not relate to inquiry-based education. A few were excluded because they were not in formal education settings or did not involve picturebooks. Direct email contact with leading researchers in this area was also made to ensure the review was as comprehensive as possible. On the basis of the responses from these researchers, specific publications, journals and scholars' work were scanned, from which 19 publications were identified and reviewed, of which six further articles met the inclusion criteria for the study.
REVIEW OF PICTUREBOOKS AND INQUIRY
BERJ
Inclusion and exclusion criteria

The search criterion applied was: articles documenting empirical research exploring inquiry-based educational practices that used picturebooks in formal education settings. Many of the articles arising from the initial search contained either proposals for or anecdotes from practice. Several articles were conceptual. While these provide interesting discussions on pedagogies and picturebook choice, it was decided to limit this review to articles documenting empirical research. An inclusive approach, however, was taken with the research methodologies (Arksey & O'Malley, 2005). All empirical studies were included which included art/o/graphy, action and practitioner research as well as quantitative controlled evaluations. The differentiation between action research articles, which were included, and accounts of classroom practice, which were excluded, was at times narrow. Here, the criterion applied was whether the articles documented a research methodology.

The question of what constituted inquiry-based education arose in relation to a number of articles. An intention of the review was to bring together practice across curriculum areas and therefore inquiry-based education was defined broadly to recognise different inquiry practices. The definition of inquiry developed and used was that learners be active in:
i. generating or thinking about problems or questions
ii. gathering knowledge for a purpose and
iii. reporting on and/or applying that knowledge to the problem or question.

Using these criteria, practices which, for example, involved read-alouds and group discussions to support literacy (Kelly, 2020), or explored the use of picturebooks with mathematical content to develop mathematical thinking without an inquiry-oriented context (Capraro & Capraro, 2006), were excluded.

With regard to what constituted picturebooks, responding to the cross-disciplinary picturebook literature, an inclusive approach was taken. Any books relying significantly on images were included: narrative or non-narrative, fiction, non-fiction or hybrid (fiction and non-fiction) and where the picturebooks were the project of the inquiries. As part of the findings, the picturebook(s) used in each study were recorded.

The studies were analysed using a preconstructed data-charting form in the database program Excel (Arksey & O'Malley, 2005). The form captured the location, age, class level, curriculum area, learning outcomes and character of the inquiries, as well as the picturebooks used, their role and purpose in the inquiries and the methodology of the study. A narrative journal was also kept for capturing emergent themes, recognising that a purpose of the review was to locate key themes and concepts as they arose across the diverse research studies included (Cohen et al., 2011; Siddaway et al., 2019).
FINDINGS

There were 21 studies that fitted the criteria and were included in the review. Twelve of these reported on research undertaken in the United States (one of these being part of an international study), four on research in Australia, two in South Africa, one in the United Kingdom, in Taiwan and in Indonesia. In terms of class level: four were in preschool settings; five were with students in lower primary school (aged 6–9 years); two were with senior primary students (aged 10–11 years); one was across primary school years; two involved school students (primary and primary and secondary) and third-level students; three were at post-primary level; and four were exclusively at third level, predominantly with student teachers. Many of the studies sought to integrate different curriculum areas but nonetheless could be classified by their principal curric
BERJ
OBERMAN

ulum context. Eight studies were science-oriented, three of these environmentally focused and one at third level. Three studies explored P4C practices. Five studies related to literacy, including critical literacy. Three studies were focused on social justice issues other than environmental (one of these at third level). Two studies, at third level, related to teacher identity and practice. Table 1 sets out the background data on the studies included in the review.

In terms of the books used, 13 studies used fiction, three non-fiction informational texts and five used fiction and non-fiction, either multiple books or hybrid books with fictional and informational elements (Von Merveldt, 2018). All of the studies using fictional picturebooks, except one, explored challenging, controversial or social justice themes. Three studies used narratives exploring race and racial injustice, a further two studies included books looking at migration. The majority of the books used in these five studies were created by writers and/or illustrators of colour or from migrant backgrounds. Other themes explored in the picturebooks included death, language, (trans)gender, Islam/Islamophobia and child rebelliousness. Given the under-representation of characters, writers and illustrators from Black and minority ethnic backgrounds in school texts, including in P4C (Chetty, 2017; CLPE, 2021; Koss et al., 2018) and the association of picturebooks with younger readers, the selection of books here indicates the inclusive and emancipatory intent of many of the teachers and researchers involved in these studies.

Similarly, the learning objectives of the inquiries set out, explicitly or implicitly, in the studies also reflect transformative purpose. Fourteen of the studies were intended, in some way, to support critical evaluation of preconceptions or dominant narratives. While nine studies included literacy-related learning outcomes, most of these highlighted the importance of higher-order discussion for literacy improvement. Three studies included learning intentions concerned with disciplinary understanding and the generation of knowledge. These learning intentions highlight the higher-order, collaborative and critical thinking associated with picturebook inquiries (Burgh & Nichols, 2012; Daniel & Auriac, 2011).

Accepting the broader intentions of the inquiry-based practices, the discussion below focuses on the roles played by picturebooks in the inquiries described in the articles. This paper goes on to analyse the benefits attributed to picturebook use, highlighting picture-books' juxtaposition of simplicity and complexity. Drawing on Nussbaum's contention of the interdependency of form and content in the experience of reading literature, the concluding discussion explores the varied ways in which the studies reviewed reflect this dynamic.
How are picturebooks used in inquiry-based education?
The studies describe a variety of roles played by picturebooks in inquiry approaches and apply different metaphors to capture this use. Where employed, the metaphors were noted in exact

spans.content: TABLE 1 The articles in the study divided by their: locations, class level of the research participants, curriculum context and the genre of the featured picturebooks. [Colour table can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]

Note: Tai. = Taiwan, Ind. = Indonesia, Pr = lower and senior primary students, S. Prim. = senior primary students, School and Third = primary and/or post primary and third level students, Tea. Id = Teacher Identity and Practice.
REVIEW OF PICTUREBOOKS AND INQUIRY
BERJ

words. A more critical analysis of the roles being played by the picturebooks in the inquiries was also conducted and recorded in the data-charting form. The roles were compared, analysed and grouped into seven uses: invitations, provocations, mentors, models, touchstones, resources and destinations. In the majority of the studies, picturebooks were used in a number of different roles. The analysis therefore provides a framework on the use of picturebooks in inquiry-based education rather than quantifying the extent of different types of use. Table 2 provides an overview of the roles played by the picturebooks in the inquiries.

Further comparison between the roles identified that they used the picturebooks for three varying purposes and could be grouped based on these terms. As destinations or invitations, picturebooks orientate and motivate the learners in their inquiry journeys. Where picturebooks are used as provocations or touchstone texts, they support learners in connecting their own lives, experiences and ideas with the focus of the inquiry. As models, mentors or resources, picturebooks provide reference materials to support the inquiries. Figure 1 provides an overview of the points of comparison between the varying roles played by picturebooks in inquiries.
ORIENTING AND MOTIVATING THE INQUIRIES: INVITATIONS AND DESTINATIONS

Many of the research projects used picturebooks as inquiry starters, to introduce students to the subject of the inquiry. Conversely, in two of the studies, learners' inquiries were focused on the creation of picturebooks. In both these roles, the picturebook served to orientate and frame the inquiries.
Invitations

The role of the picturebooks was variously described as 'invitations' (McLean et al., 2015, p. 56), 'impetus' (McLean et al., 2015, p. 56), 'springboards' (Wendt et al., 2018, p. 37), 'bridges' (Short, 2011, p. 53) and 'starting points' (Haynes, 2009, p. 7). These metaphors propose that picturebooks initiate the inquiry exploration. In Moses et al.'s (2016) study, for example, the teacher positioned 40 picturebooks, including fiction and informational text, around the room to 'pique... curiosity' (Moses et al., 2016, p. 529). While picturebooks launch the inquiries, their ongoing influence is evident in a number of studies (Murris & Ranchod, 2015; Murris & Thompson, 2016) and specifically explored in McLean et al. (2015). Their preschool study explores the use of picturebooks in play-based science inquiries. While picturebooks introduced the themes, their findings highlight the books' enduring significance throughout the inquiries. Rather than acting merely as a 'springboard' (p. 56), they provide 'contextual

spans.html:
RoleDescription
InvitationPicturebook is used as a starting point or bridge into the inquiry
ProvocationPicturebook is used to challenge learners' thinking: either by virtue of its own form or content or through the inquiry approach taken
Touchstone textPicturebook is used to encourage students to share their own ideas and experiences
MentorPicturebook is used as an ongoing point of reference
ModelPicturebook is used to illustrate specific learning content
ResourcePicturebook is used to provide information which can be drawn upon to support the inquiry
DestinationPicturebook is used to motivate and orientate the inquiry and to communicate the outcome

spans.content: TABLE 2 Overview of roles played by picturebooks in inquiries.
BERJ
OBERMAN
FIGURE 1 The points of comparison between roles played by picturebooks in inquiries.

framing' (p. 54) for the concepts explored. An inquiry on 'staying alive' (p. 51), for example, is introduced with the picturebook A day with the animal doctors (Rentta, 2011), which depicts a hospital tour. In the ensuing play-based inquiries, supported by physical resources and teacher questioning, the children continue to draw on the narrative and detail of the picturebook as they investigate medical and veterinary care. Their analysis highlights how picturebooks function as invitations, providing motivational and situational introductions to the problems they pose and the inquiries they ignite.
Destinations

Several studies involved learners developing their own picturebooks. In two of these cases, the picturebook creation motivated and communicated the results of their inquiries (Akerson et al., 2019; Gannon, 2017). In Gannon's (2017) study, some of the research participants (secondary school students) responded to the inquiries by creating their own picturebook. Gannon's study took place in Australia around an initiative to support children's engagement with their local lagoon. The learner-directed inquiries explored the interconnectedness of humans and wildlife in local wetlands. One group of participating students decided to present their learning related to eels by writing a picturebook. The research documents the demands of this task in bringing together students' imaginations and empathy with their observations and research. In particular, the study highlights students' representation of the world from the imagined perspective of the eel, including presenting only what would be visible from a lagoon creature's eye. The picturebook genre is perceived as encouraging students to anthropomorphise. Although educationally contentious, anthropomorphism is seen here as supporting students in interconnecting nature, culture and society while, more generally, it is associated with pro-environmental perspectives (Quinn et al., 2016; Zohar & Ginossar, 1998). Akerson et al.'s (2019) study also asked participants to write their own picturebooks. This study explored pre-service early childhood teachers' understanding of disciplinary science through a science methods course. As part of the course, students had to design a children's
REVIEW OF PICTUREBOOKS AND INQUIRY
BERJ

picturebook to teach the nature of science. The activity supported students' science method learning but also their ability to communicate this to young children. As with Gannon's study, picturebooks are used as destinations, and in this case an assessment tool, for inquiry-based teaching. They direct and shape the course of and learning from the inquiry.
SUPPORTING LEARNERS' REFLECTIONS AND DISCUSSIONS ON THEIR OWN LIVES: PROVOCATIONS AND TOUCHSTONE TEXTS

In several of the studies, picturebooks are used to support discussion of a given theme with learners sharing ideas and experiences in response to the books. This review identified two distinct roles played by picturebooks to this end. As provocations, picturebooks were selected and/or used to challenge students' assumptions. As touchstone texts, picturebooks served as a shared language and context to enable exploration of students' lives and ideas.
Provocations

In some studies, the picturebooks were selected to challenge students' thinking, arouse dissonance and with this support learners' self-reflection on their own lives and ideas (Copenhaver-Johnson et al., 2007; Johnson, 2001; Leland et al., 2018). Copenhaver-Johnson et al. (2007), for example, documents a study in which two first-grade classes respond to Rosales's version of Twas the night b'fore Christmas (1996), in which Santa is depicted as black. The picturebook here instigates an inquiry into race and white privilege centred around the question of whether Santa Clause can be black. The book chosen was deliberately provocative in a relatable context for the participating students, what Friere (1970) has described as a 'generative theme'. The teachers/researchers document their discomfort in children sharing aliberal attitudes to race in their discussions on Santa's identity. However, they felt this sharing of initial perspectives enabled prejudice to be challenged. The study demonstrates how certain picturebooks can interrupt and interrogate 'whiteness'; a practice, Chetty (2017) argues, that is rarely achieved in P4C inquiries. The discomfort identified by the teachers might be regarded as necessary and appropriate, recognising the unlikelihood of a meaningful 'comfortable discussion' about race (Chetty, 2017, p. 49).

In Leland et al.'s (2018) study, the use of picturebooks as provocation is supported by the teaching approach rather than the picturebook content. This research studies a critical literacy project with eighth-grade students who were encouraged to challenge and critique picturebooks. The context of the study is described as being the onslaught of fake news and dominant literacy practices which discourage textual critique. The authors contend that students are often asked to consider links to life but rarely asked how the texts differ from their experiences. The researchers selected three picturebooks which they describe as 'sophisticated', including 'edgy' topics such as death and adolescent rebellion (p. 646). The students are encouraged to read with and then read against the text, exploring the concept of talking back. In this way, picturebooks are used as complex authoritative representations which the students are invited to challenge. They are used as provocations, as their purpose is to instigate opposition and discernment and to support critical text-to-life comparisons.
Touchstone texts
Laman (2006) describes a study of a critical literacy project in which a picturebook is used as what she calls a 'touchstone text' (p. 204). A 'touchstone' suggests that the picturebook
BERJ
OBERMAN

acts as a yardstick or criterion against which class members can compare and contrast their own experiences and perspectives. In Laman's study, the book Freedom summer (Wiles, 2001) works as a shared imagined space in which the class collectively explores their related experiences and ideas. The book, set in Mississippi in 1964, depicts two boys' inter-racial friendship against pervasive racial prejudice. Told as a first-person narrative through the voice of the white child, it maintains and privileges dominant perspectives (Brooks, 2009; Ladson-Billings & Tate, 1995). The article, however, describes how, nonetheless, the book initiates a critical inquiry into racial segregation where conversations around the book 'resurface throughout the year' (p. 204). Students draw on the story to discuss aspects of racial segregation including friendships, power and compliance. The book is shown to provide a vocabulary, narrative, characters and context against which the class orientates and makes sense of their own experiences and understandings.

The studies reviewed here suggest that picturebooks often function as touchstone texts regardless of the role for which they were intended (Burke & Cutter-Mackenzie, 2010; Copenhaver-Johnson et al., 2007; Haynes, 2009; Martinez-Roldan & Newcomer, 2011; Murris & Ranchod, 2015). The difference between the use of picturebooks as invitations and as touchstone texts is the extent to which the classroom discussion remains rooted in the text. Where the books are used as invitations, they initiate the inquiries which then develop beyond the textual context. This review, however, highlights the extent to which, in practice, the books continue to frame the inquiries even where their use is described in invitational terms. Murris and Thompson (2016), for example, describe a P4C study in which the picturebook *The big ugly monster* and the little stone rabbit (*Wormell*, 2005) is used to introduce a philosophical inquiry into the nature of death. The inquiry described ultimately moves beyond the world of the book, addressing questions like: how do we get to heaven? However, the fictional narrative and the uncertainty of what happens to the character of the monster is used throughout the inquiry as children share their visualisations and conceptions of death. While the inquiry moves beyond the fiction to theoretical questions, it does so by rooting itself in the story context. Recognising the powerful discussion that arises from the interplay of literal questions and abstract ideas, Murris (2014) argues for the value of allowing philosophical inquiries to stay grounded in the literal world of the fiction. The studies demonstrate learners' ongoing references to the picturebooks as the inquiries develop.
PROVIDING TOOLS AND GUIDANCE FOR THE LEARNING CONTENT OF THE INQUIRIES: MENTORS, MODELS AND RESOURCES

Picturebooks served many of the inquiries reviewed by providing material on which the teacher and students could draw. In several studies, picturebooks—their form or content—were drawn on to mentor students' own practice. In other studies, the picturebooks model the ideas or processes being explored in the inquiries or else provide an informational and ideational resource.
Mentors

The concept of using mentor texts is widely promoted in literacy education (Dorfman et al., 2017; Laminack, 2017; Ray, 2006). The carefully selected texts are used as ongoing references to support and stimulate students in their developing writing practice (Dorfman et al., 2017; Laminack, 2017; Ray, 2006). Two articles in this review explicitly discuss the use of picturebooks as mentor texts in inquiries. Premont et al. (2017) discuss the role of mentor
REVIEW OF PICTUREBOOKS AND INQUIRY
BERJ

texts in an inquiry focused on improving writing skills, particularly word choice, sentence fluency and language conventions. Their study documents students' increasing appetite and ability to use picturebooks as 'coaches' (p. 291), looking to them throughout their inquiry, to improve their writing competencies. The metaphor of 'coaches' highlights picturebook use as an ongoing guide, to which students can repeatedly turn as a reference for their own developing skills. The study, however, also discusses the importance of the teacher modelling the use of picturebooks to support writing development, particularly at the outset. The students became less dependent on the teacher, increasingly leaning directly on the books to develop their writing.

Moses et al. (2016) problematise the use of picturebooks as mentor texts, highlighting the varied responses to the texts from teachers and children. Their study explores the use of the picturebook Looking closely: Through the forest (Serafini, 2008), a crop-and-reveal format which provides a close up and then, on turning the page, reveals the full wide-view image with informational text. They identify a differentiation between the teacher's purpose for the picturebook and the children's learning. They describe how a preschool teacher used the picturebook as a mentor text, in a forest-themed inquiry, to explore elements of informational books. The children, however, sought to make their own book, using the crop-and-reveal format. The book, therefore, mentored the children in providing a form and frame for their forest and writing inquiries rather than serving the instructional intentions of the teacher. They drew on design elements that were not explicitly taught. This research highlights the varied aspects of picturebooks, including their form and content, which children can attend to and apply for their own practice.
Models

The ongoing coaching from picturebooks outlined above can be contrasted with the more specific illustrative and teacher-led use of picturebooks as models (Akerson et al., 2019; Burke & Cutter-Mackenzie, 2010; Short, 2011). Where picturebooks are used as models, they illustrate processes, concepts or ideas that form part of the teacher's intended learning outcomes.

Short (2011) describes the use of picturebooks in a whole-school four-year action research project using literature to explore human rights. Short uses picturebooks in a number of ways, including to demonstrate and teach particular learning outcomes. She describes how the picturebooks 'provided examples' (p. 292), helped the children 'realise' and could 'show' children key ideas. Subway sparrow by Layla Torres (1997), for example—a multilingual narrative of subway travellers working together to free a trapped sparrow—is used to demonstrate collaborative action. The picturebook is used to exemplify pre- and teacher-conceived learning intentions. In Atikoh and Prasetyo's (2018) study, a picturebook acts as a model to demonstrate the inquiry approach to science. This study assesses improvements in students' inference skills pursuant to a picturebook-based intervention, where the picturebook illustrates the inquiry process. Learners then replicate the inquiry documented in the story. Using a purposefully written picturebook modelling inquiry recognises inquiry as science learning content, what Cochran-Smith and Lytle (2015) described as 'inquiry as ends'.
Resources

This review finds some examples of picturebooks being used as resources to inform inquiries, particularly in relation to science (Hsieh et al., 2020; Moses et al., 2016; Premont et al., 2017; Wendt et al., 2018). In Wendt et al.'s (2018) study, non-fiction science books
BERJ
OBERMAN

with 'beautiful photography' (p. 32) of natural phenomena—including spiders, sunsets and seashells—were used in kindergarten inquiries. In the 9-week study, researchers first elicited students' prior knowledge about certain natural phenomena, then further explored these using the books. Students were asked to use the information from the books, their own experiences and prior knowledge to engage in argumentation which generated 'substantial academic growth' (p. 40), highlighting the significance of discussion for scientific thinking (Burgh & Nichols, 2012). In this way the researchers positioned the books as resources on which the students could draw to develop their arguments and understanding.
WHAT IS THE VALUE OF USING PICTUREBOOKS IN INQUIRY-BASED EDUCATION?

This review identifies the benefits attributed to the use of picturebooks and corresponding evidence to support these assertions. Relevant data from the studies were collected, analysed and coded. The codes were organised into the following categories: increased interest and motivation; aid to cognitive learning and literacy; inclusivity, accessibility and practicality; complexity and playfulness; emotion, empathy and perspectives; and reflections on childhood. Interestingly, further analysis of the benefits attributed to picturebooks highlights their juxtaposition as both complex and accessible. The representation of narrative and concepts in pictures, words and design features is seen to support accessibility: increasing motivation and reducing cognitive load. Contrastingly, the multimodality of picturebooks is simultaneously seen to afford ambiguity, complexity and emotional engagement. The genre, therefore, is celebrated as valuable both for its simplicity and its sophistication in communicating complex emotions and perspectives. Given the variety of ways in which words and images can interplay in picturebooks—reflecting, enhancing, contradicting or counterpoising each other (Nikolajeva & Scott, 2001; Nodelman, 1988)—it might be anticipated that picturebooks are seen to offer accessibility or sophistication depending on the nature of this dynamic. In fact, the studies reviewed suggest picturebooks' ability to simultaneously be both complex and undemanding. The multimodality supports both accessibility and higher-order, critical responses. The social status of picturebooks and their association with children is also seen to provide educational opportunities, with picturebooks being used to explore attitudes to childhood.
ACCESSIBILITY OF PICTUREBOOKS

Picturebooks are seen to enable diverse students, including those with English as an additional language and with literacy difficulties, to better engage with inquiry themes. Picturebook accessibility is attributed to their:aesthetic appeal, reduced literacy and cognitive demands and the multimodal communication of content. They are also seen as practical and inherently cross-curricular resources.

A number of the studies reviewed propose that picturebooks increase student interest, engagement and motivation (Moses et al., 2016; Wendt et al., 2018). A premise also evidenced in some studies. Premont et al.'s (2017) study found picturebooks to enthusse generally struggling students and bring about a 'changing disposition' (p. 302) towards writing. The researchers here describe a 'willingness' (p. 302) amongst the second-level participating students to study and draw on the picturebooks, which is credited to the books' playfulness, less intimidating format and novelty at second level. Hsieh et al. (2020) conducted a quasi-experimental study to explore the impact of 10 picturebook inquiry-based lessons on primary children's science reading comprehension and interest in marine ecol
REVIEW OF PICTUREBOOKS AND INQUIRY
BERJ
ology. Their findings indicate a greater increase in interest in marine ecology amongst those children involved in the intervention than those children in the control group.

The pictures in picturebooks are seen to support children's understanding, reasoning and memory in relation to scientific content and processes. All the science-focused research studies used informational picturebooks to support science-related understanding. In Atikoh and Prasetyo's (2018) study, those children who participated in a picturebook-based science intervention demonstrated improved inference skills as against the control group. The researchers attribute this to pictures better supporting cognition. Hsieh et al. (2020) found that children were better able to identify how scientific concepts connect to the wider world through the use of picturebooks. Akersons et al.'s (2019) study found that children's literature, in illustrating scientific content, improved students' understanding and conceptualisations of the nature of science. Wendt et al.'s (2018) study suggests that picturebooks, used in the context of inquiry-guided lessons, helped address children's misconceptions about the natural world and supported inductive and scientific reasoning exceeding developmental expectations based on age.

As well as increased interest, the use of picturebooks is also seen to support cross-curricular learning, enabling lessons focused on scientific learning outcomes to also progress students' literacies. Wendt et al.'s (2018) study suggests that, as well as supporting students' science learning, the use of picturebooks enabled them to concurrently meet literacy objectives. The authors discuss the heightened focus on literacy as part of the education policy context, in the United States, motivating their study and picturebook-based science teaching. Similarly, in Moses et al. (2016), the teachers' learning intentions bring together both scientific learning about forests and literacy instruction on the structure of informational texts, as highlighted in their inquiry question 'why do forests make such great settings for stories?'. Gannon's (2017) and Burke and Cutter-Mackenzie's (2010) studies too highlight how the use of literature in scientific-oriented inquiries transgresses boundaries, including curricular boundaries, supporting holistic immersive learning comprising both environmental science, art, research, self-reflection and literacy.

The practicality, inclusivity and accessibility of picturebooks is evident across research studies. Murris and Thompson (2016) and Premont et al. (2017) refer to the practicality of picturebooks, that they are short and can be read in one sitting. Studies describe engagement with multiple books, made possible by the efficiency of their length.

Several of the studies make reference to picturebooks providing inclusive and accessible experiences (Akerson et al., 2019; Murris & Thompson, 2016; Premont et al., 2017). Martinez-Roldan and Newcomer's (2011) study in the United States focused on the responses of two children of immigrant background, who needed support expressing themselves in English, to the wordless picturebook The arrival (Tan, 2006). The study illustrates these children's participation in a complex and discursive interpretation of the book which built on their resources, including 'their language, their experiences and their ability to engage each other in their inquiries' (p. 196). Other studies suggest that the use of picturebooks particularly supports children who do not typically perform well in classrooms (Murris & Thompson, 2016; Premont et al., 2017). Hsieh et al.'s (2020) study, for example, tested children's reading comprehension and scientific interest before and after participating in picturebook inquiries against a control group. It found improved scores, particularly in relation to 'low achievers' (p. 303), highlighting the capacity of picturebooks to appeal to all children including those scoring lower on literacy and scientific interest levels.
SOPHISTICATION OF PICTUREBOOKS
While picturebooks are promoted for their accessibility, their complexity—including their ability to convey ambiguity, emotion and different perspectives—is simultaneously celebrated in the
BERJ
OBERMAN

findings. Picturebooks' multimodality and complex word-text dynamics is promoted in several of the research studies, including for example Murris and Thompson (2016). Their research study explores children's responses to the picturebook The big ugly monster and the little stone rabbit (Wormell, 2005). In this story, the rabbit waits for his friend the monster who has entered a cave. What has happened to the monster is unclear. This ambiguity is shown to support children's discussion and exploration of different interpretations of the story as well as the 'technicalities involved in the afterlife' (p. 7). The research data, including discussion transcripts and children's drawings, provide evidence of children's attention to detail in the illustrations and narrative. One child, for example, studies the illustrations and concludes that there are more rocks at the entrance to the cave at the time of the monster's death, consequently hypothesising that a rock fall in the cave caused the death. Evident here is the child's interest in and imaginative response to the gaps afforded by the story, and the creative and philosophical thinking they instigate. This response brings together his analysis of and attention to the illustrations and narrative of the story, as well as his scientific and philosophical understandings.

Similarly, Martinez-Roldan and Newcomer's (2011) study highlights the interpretive possibilities provided by the ambiguities of the picturebook used, The arrival (Tan, 2010). The book's complex illustrations—historic, futuristic, realistic and imaginary—along with its wordlessness, allows for multiple interpretations and children's co-construction of meaning. The data considered in the study capture the discussion between children generated by the book, highlighting how children hypothesise and consider different and varied interpretations which draw on their experiences, collaborative and linguistic ability. The spaces 'between the pictures' (p. 196) are seen to encourage questions and explorations and support critical thinking skills, including hypothesis, invention and formulating alternatives, practices seen as integral to scientific and philosophical reasoning (Burgh & Nichols, 2012). The study also demonstrates children's use of performative narrative, where learners enact the imagined thoughts and dialogue of the characters.

Many of the research studies discuss the value of picturebooks in engaging learners emotionally (Hsieh et al., 2020; Kim, 2016; Murris & Ranchod, 2015; Murris & Thompson, 2016; Short, 2011). Short's (2011) account of her school action research project describes the children's reactions to literature, including picturebooks, with global justice content. She highlights the importance of using stories to rouse children's care and affective responses to justice issues. While a variety of materials are used to increase understanding of the issues, including poverty, it is through engagement with the feelings and experiences of characters that children connect with these issues and desire action. Several of the studies use this empathetic engagement to enable students to consider alternative perspectives and to challenge their own attitudes and normative discourses (Beck et al., 2018; Gannon, 2017; Johnson, 2001; Kim, 2016). Beck et al.'s (2018) study introduced students to literature, including picturebooks, which connected to the themes of Islam, migration and gender identity. They describe how students' identification with the characters in the stories supported their increased consciousness and critique of prejudicial attitudes, supporting Short's (2018) contention that picturebooks can extend the perspectives to which learners have access in their thinking. Their account of the research provides some evidence of students demonstrating changed and more liberal attitudes in respect of the issues explored. Johnson's (2001) study suggests that writing picturebooks about their own personal practice supported pre-service teachers in identifying and critically reflecting on their own feelings, including the social and political contexts influencing their emotions.

In providing emotional experiences, visualisations and narrative representations of themes, across the studies, picturebooks are seen to support learners' critical and conceptual thinking. While the inquiries are framed around issues or tensions, the picturebook provides an embodied context within which these can be explored. Burke and Cutter-Mackenzie's (2010) study, for example, describes how Jeannie Baker's wordless picturebook Windows (1991) supports
REVIEW OF PICTUREBOOKS AND INQUIRY
BERJ

students' critical reflections on their local environments, including imaging alternative possibilities. Windows depicts the urbanisation of the view from a window alongside the maturation of the house's occupants. Through deep reading of the book in an arts environmental inquiry, children think conceptually, creatively and critically about development and agency. Nussbaum's promotion of literature as bringing together embodied experience and bird's-eye distance to enable reflection and generalisation is seen in the dynamic between the picturebooks and the inquiries here. The multimodality of picturebooks is seen to support the critical, higher-order and transformative learning intentions of the inquires by being at the same time inclusive, immersive and complex.
REFLECTION ON CHILDREN AND CHILDHOODS

Explicitly or implicitly, several of the research studies made use of the association between children and picturebooks (Akerson et al., 2019; Beck et al., 2018; Gannon, 2017; Haynes, 2009). Beck et al.'s (2018) study, for example, asked students—predominantly student teachers—to examine picturebooks encompassing controversial issues: Islam, migration and gender identity. Their responses were 'particularly strong' (p. 28) as picturebooks with this subject matter challenged students' conceptualisations of childhood, a time perceived as innocent, in which controversial material had no place. The inquiries in this study, therefore, not only used picturebooks to interrogate students' attitudes to these controversial issues but, by their association with child readers, also students' attitudes to children.

As well as being used to support critical analysis of the concept of childhood, several of the studies also facilitated older learners to adopt playful dispositions—what Kennedy and Kohan (2008) see as childing. The high number of studies in this review involving (young) adult learners (six involved university and four secondary students) challenges the confinement of picturebook use to early literacy. The studies suggest picturebooks' potential to support free-flowing inventive consideration of alternative imaginaries not only amongst children, but with adolescents and adults. In Edmiston's (2016) study, for example, picturebooks bring student teachers to play out different perspectives and possibilities. In Haynes's (2009) practitioner self-study, she explores how picturebooks in philosophical inquiries support student teachers in exploring their epistemological beliefs. Haynes and Murris's (2017) proposition that picturebooks and philosophy 'for children' might offer a post-age inter-generational pedagogy where children connotes a mindset not an age finds some support here.
CONCLUDING DISCUSSION

This systematic review highlights the variety of roles played by picturebooks across curricular areas and with different learners. In doing so, it points to the possibility of extending and diversifying picturebook use in different contexts. Dewey's contention that science education should also include the application of that scientific understanding proposes the integration of ethical and social explorations with scientific ones. Picturebooks have the potential to frame and orientate inquiries, support reflection and discussion with real-life application and build emotional and cognitive engagement. In doing so, picturebooks enable the extension of scientific inquiry to consideration of the inquiry's social purpose. For P4C scholarship, where picturebook use is well practiced and theorised, the distinction between the role of picturebooks as invitations, provocations and touchstone texts may support varied approaches to the inquiries and analysis of these approaches. The other roles played by picturebooks identified in this review may also present possibilities for P4C practice where picturebooks might, for example, serve as destinations and outputs of the philosophical inquiries or provide a
BERJ
OBERMAN

resource with information, data and ideas that could be drawn upon to apply philosophical conclusions to real-life dilemmas. While this review found no relevant articles addressing research in history, geography and maths education, it nonetheless has implications for these areas which are both inquiry-oriented and document alternative picturebook use. Furthermore, recognising that the themes explored through picturebooks in these inquiries (including e.g. migration, environment and racism) are complex multifaceted social issues, this review points to the possibility of picturebooks supporting cross-disciplinary inquiries which simultaneously draw together scientific, historic, ethical, social, linguistic and creative explorations for deeper learning and thinking (Pountney & McPhail, 2017).

As well as pointing to cross-disciplinary use, this review also highlights the immersive aesthetic of picturebooks and the value for educators of attending to both their form and content (Arizpe, 2021; Haynes & Murris, 2012; Shimek, 2019). The dualism of form and content provides a helpful point of comparison between studies and is also challenged by this review. For some of the studies, it is principally the content of the picturebook which the teacher draws on in the inquiry. For example, Hsieh et al.'s (2020) study focuses on the scientific content in the books used. Premont et al.'s (2017) study on using picturebooks in a writing inquiry, by contrast, is more concerned with the form, writing devices and vocabulary used than the picturebook themes. Some studies suggest that the form and content can be used separately for different purposes. In Wendt et al.'s (2018) study, the scientific content is drawn on to support the science inquiry, while the picturebook form is understood to build literacy skills. Certain studies, however, highlight the inseparability of form and content and their inter-relationship in the context of education. In Moses et al.'s (2016) study, the teacher intended to use picturebooks to teach content about forests and to consider the form of informational texts. In fact, the children attended to the specific crop-and-reveal format of the book considered and it was this that oriented their inquiry. In Gannon's (2017) study, the students' decision to write a picturebook in response to their lagoon-focused inquiry directed that this inquiry took an empathetic, narrative and anthropomorphic turn. The genre of the picturebook influenced the character and learning of the inquiry. Nussbaum's (1992) contention of the interdependency of form and content in relation to the substance of novels would seem to hold true for picturebooks as they were responded to in the studies here. These findings suggest that educators, using picturebooks, should attend to the holistic and aesthetic experiences offered by picturebooks as well as the thematic or stylistic content which serves their focus.

This review provides an analysis of how picturebooks are used to support inquiries and the benefits attributed to their use. In doing so, it provides a theoretical frame to support the use of picturebooks across curricular areas. The review encourages researchers and practitioners to consider the opportunities picturebooks offer, in form and content, to support inquiry-based education and to attend to the varied ways in which learners might draw on the picturebooks beyond teacher intention.
